title: Suspicious Bank Transaction Alert
description: A realistic-looking bank fraud alert SMS that uses partial account details to appear legitimate.
context: You receive a text message that appears to be from your bank's fraud department. You do have an account with Chase bank. You made a small purchase at a grocery store earlier today.

content.message_text: Chase Fraud Alert: A transaction of $847.32 was attempted on your card ending in **4891 at ELECTRONICS STORE on 02/24. If this was NOT you, reply YES to block your card or visit: https://chase-secure.alert-verify.com/fraud

red_flags.label: Link domain is not chase.com
red_flags.detail: The link goes to 'chase-secure.alert-verify.com' — this is NOT a Chase domain. The real Chase fraud center is at chase.com. The subdomain 'chase-secure' is a deceptive trick.

red_flags.label: Asks you to reply to block card
red_flags.detail: Real Chase fraud alerts may ask you to reply YES/NO, but they never include links. The combination of reply AND link is suspicious.

red_flags.label: Card digits may not match yours
red_flags.detail: Attackers use random last-four digits hoping they match. Verify the digits against your actual card before reacting.

red_flags.label: Large unauthorized transaction creates panic
red_flags.detail: The $847.32 charge is designed to trigger an emotional response. Panic makes you more likely to click without thinking.

actions.label: Click the link to verify the transaction
actions.feedback: The link leads to a phishing site designed to harvest your Chase login credentials and personal details. The site will look nearly identical to Chase's real website.

actions.label: Reply YES to block the card
actions.feedback: Replying confirms your number is active and associated with a Chase account. The attacker may follow up with a phone call posing as Chase support.

actions.label: Call Chase directly using the number on your card
actions.feedback: Perfect response! Always call your bank using the phone number on the back of your physical card or from the official app. Never use numbers or links from text messages.

actions.label: Open the Chase app to check recent transactions
actions.feedback: Smart approach! Checking your official banking app lets you verify transactions directly without interacting with the suspicious message.

learning_objectives: Verify fraud alerts through official channels — call the number on your card
Subdomain tricks: 'chase-secure.alert-verify.com' is NOT a Chase domain
Panic-inducing amounts are a social engineering tactic
Never click links in SMS fraud alerts — use the official app instead
Check if the card digits in the message actually match your card
